claim: The original US constitution was written on parchment.

supporting.text: Historical records indicate that the original US Constitution was handwritten on parchment, a durable material made from animal skin.

attacks.text: Historical records indicate that the original US Constitution was handwritten on parchment, a durable material made from animal skin.
Some historical documents from the same era were written on vellum, a finer type of parchment, and it's possible the Constitution could have been on vellum instead.
Official records and expert analyses confirm that the original US Constitution was specifically on parchment, not vellum, as vellum was typically reserved for more decorative or ceremonial documents.
There is no surviving original document to physically verify the material, as the Constitution is now preserved under glass and cannot be tested.
Multiple contemporaneous accounts and conservation records from the National Archives provide consistent documentation that the original was on parchment.

supporting.text: The National Archives displays the original US Constitution, which is visibly written on parchment, confirming its material.

attacks.text: The National Archives displays the original US Constitution, which is visibly written on parchment, confirming its material.
The National Archives could display a replica or facsimile of the original Constitution, not the actual parchment.
The National Archives explicitly states that they display the original Constitution, not a replica, and provides provenance documentation.
Parchment can degrade over time, and the displayed document may not be the original due to preservation concerns.
The National Archives uses advanced preservation techniques to maintain the original Constitution's integrity, ensuring it remains the same document.

supporting.text: Parchment was the standard material for important legal documents in the 18th century, making it the likely medium for the Constitution.

attacks.text: Parchment was the standard material for important legal documents in the 18th century, making it the likely medium for the Constitution.
Some important 18th-century documents were written on vellum or high-quality paper, not necessarily parchment.
Historical records explicitly confirm that the US Constitution was written on parchment, not vellum or paper.
Parchment was expensive and not always available, so alternatives might have been used for drafts or copies.
The National Archives holds the original Constitution, which is confirmed to be on parchment, not a draft or copy.

supporting.text: The physical preservation efforts of the original US Constitution focus on parchment, as it is the material on which it was written.

attacks.text: The physical preservation efforts of the original US Constitution focus on parchment, as it is the material on which it was written.
The original US Constitution could have been written on multiple materials, and parchment preservation efforts do not conclusively prove it was the sole material used.
Historical records and expert consensus confirm parchment as the exclusive material for the original US Constitution, supported by direct examination of the document.
Preservation efforts might prioritize parchment due to its durability, not necessarily because it was the only material used originally.
Contemporary accounts and material analysis confirm no other materials were used for the original Constitution, making parchment the definitive medium.
